title: Ranking every player that Arsenal have signed directly from Chelsea after Raheem Sterling deal

Ranking every player that Arsenal have signed from Chelsea after Kepa, Madueke deals
Arsenal and Chelsea have a bitter rivalry on the pitch but that hasnâ€™t stopped a number of players from making the switch from west to north London.
Kepa Arrizabalaga completed a Â£5million move to Arsenal earlier this summer and has now been joined at the Emirates by Noni Madueke, who cost Â£52million.
Weâ€™ve taken a look at the other nine players that Arsenal have signed from Chelsea and ranked them by how they fared in north London.
Note: weâ€™ve only included transfers in the Premier League era so that omits George Graham and Billy Dickson.
9. Willian
Year: 2020
Arsenal appearances: 37
Arsenal goals: 1
Willian enjoyed a successful seven-year spell with Chelsea, winning two Premier League titles, an FA Cup, the League Cup and the Europa League.
He wanted to extend his stay at Stamford Bridge beyond the end of the 2019/20 season, but the Blues would not sanction a new three-year deal.
The former Brazil international then left Chelsea on a free transfer and found the three-year deal he was after at the Emirates.
His Arsenal career got off to an excellent start as he registered two assists in a 3-0 victory over Fulham on the opening day of the 2020/21 season.
But thatâ€™s as good as it got for the winger, who suffered a woeful drop in form and finished the 2020/21 season with just one goal in 37 appearances in all competitions.
Willian became a much-maligned figure at the Emirates and agreed to terminate his three-year contract in August 2021 â€“ just 12 months after arriving at the club.
â€œYes it did,â€ he said when asked if hateful messages from Arsenal fans influenced his decision to leave.
â€œI received a lot of messages on social media from them, but also because I came from Chelsea I think if I came from another club maybe the fans would be better.
â€œBut because I come from Chelsea and I didnâ€™t perform well and because of them, I think about that and I have to go.â€

8. Lassana Diarra
Year: 20
Arsenal appearances: 13
Arsenal goals: 0
Diarra won Chelseaâ€™s Young Player of the Year award in 2005/06, but he failed to usurp Claude Makelele and made just 31 appearances for the club.
The midfielder decided to leave Stamford Bridge in search of more first-team football and joined Arsenal on transfer deadline day in 2007.
But he was also unable to establish himself at the Emirates, featuring only 13 times in all competitions before joining Portsmouth in a Â£5.5million deal in January 2008.
â€œI did not learn anything from [Arsene] Wenger,â€ he said when reflecting on his unhappy four-and-a-half-month stint at Arsenal. â€œHe just taught me to doubt everything. The relationship I had with him was not good.
â€œYou cannot understand the whole world. I respect the way you train, but I learned more with [Jose] Mourinho. Mourinho taught me to fight. I spoke looking into his eyes.
â€œIf you had a problem, it would be discussed. Wenger never addressed me until I told him I was going. He talked to others, but not me. I feel like I never played for Arsenal. If people do not remind me of them [Arsenal], I forget about them. Itâ€™s erased from my memory.â€
7. Raheem Sterling
Year: 2024
Arsenal appearances: 28
Arsenal goals: 1
After being deemed surplus to requirements by Chelsea manager Enzo Maresca, Sterling joined Arsenal on transfer deadline day on a season-long loan deal.
The move to north London saw him reunite with Mikel Arteta, having previously worked under the Spanish coach during his time at Manchester City.
â€œWe all know Raheemâ€™s qualities, he is a top talent with a lot of experience who can help the team in a big way,â€ Arteta said.
But the England international was unable to show those qualities in an Arsenal shirt, registering just one goal and five assists in 28 appearances for the club.
The Gunners decided not to pursue a permanent move for the winger, and he returned to Chelsea at the end of the 2024/25 season.
6. Yossi Benayoun
Year: 2011
Arsenal appearances: 25
Arsenal goals: 6
Thirteen years before Sterling, Benayoun also left Chelsea and completed a season-long loan move to Arsenal on transfer deadline day.
â€œI first heard about the interest from Arsenal eight days before the end of the window and when I knew they wanted me it was an easy choice,â€ he said.
â€œI had a few good options from clubs in England and outside but as soon as I heard about Arsenal my mind was made up.â€
The midfielder initially struggled to break into Wengerâ€™s team in the first half of the 2011/12 season but proved to be a useful addition for the Gunners.
He produced his best performances in an Arsenal shirt during a 5-2 win over Tottenham and a 1-0 win over Manchester City. His displays in both games saw him receive standing ovations from the Emirates faithful.
The winger also scored in a 3-2 win over West Brom on the final day of the Premier League season, which helped Arsenal finish above Tottenham and secure Champions League qualification.
But his overall record of six goals and three assists in 25 appearances in all competitions wasnâ€™t enough to earn him a permanent deal at the Emirates.
5. David Luiz
Year: 2019
Arsenal appearances: 73
Arsenal goals: 4
After being deemed surplus to requirements by the then-Chelsea manager Frank Lampard, Luiz joined Arsenal in an Â£8million deal.
His two seasons at the Emirates were punctuated by a catalogue of errors, most notably in that cameo performance away at Manchester City in the first match of project restart.
Remarkably, the centre-back earned three red cards and conceded six penalties during his 53 Premier League appearances for the Gunners. In comparison, he received just one red card and gave away three penalties during 160 league games for Chelsea.
But Luiz did play a key role in Arsenalâ€™s FA Cup success in 2019/20, producing a Man of the Match performance against Manchester City in the semi-final before helping the Gunners beat Chelsea in the final.
The former Brazil international also brought a wealth of experience into the dressing room and some of the young stars at Arsenal have praised him for assisting their development.

4. William Gallas
Year: 20o5
Arsenal appearances: 142
Arsenal goals: 17
Gallas played a key role in Chelseaâ€™s early success under Jose Mourinho, helping the club win back-to-back Premier League titles in 2004/05 and 2005/06.
But things eventually turned sour and he reportedly threatened to score an own goal if he was selected for Chelseaâ€™s first game of the 2006/07 season.
The centre-back then moved to Arsenal on transfer deadline day as part of the deal that saw Ashley Cole go in the opposite direction.
His time at the Emirates is best remembered for that strop on the pitch at Birmingham City in February 2008, but he did a decent job for the Gunners.
The former France international made 142 appearances in all competitions and also scored 17 goals, including a winner against Chelsea in December 2007.
He left on a free transfer at the end of the 2009/10 season and joined Tottenham â€“ making him the first man to have played for Chelsea, Arsenal and Spurs.
3. Kai Havertz
Year: 2023
Arsenal appearances: 87
Arsenal goals: 29
Despite scoring the winning goal in the 2021 Champions League final, Havertz failed to live up to expectations during his three-year stint at Chelsea.
Eyebrows were raised when Arsenal decided to fork out an initial Â£60million and another Â£5million in potential add-ons to sign him in the summer of 2023.
The Germany international endured a slow start to life in north London as he struggled to adapt to his role as a No.8 in Artetaâ€™s midfield.
But he flourished as a centreâ€‘forward in the second half of his debut season, finishing the campaign with 14 goals and eight assists in all competitions.
The 26-year-old registered 20 direct goal contributions in 2024/25 but now faces a fight for his place in the first team due to the impending arrival of Viktor Gyokeres.
2. Jorginho
Year: 2023
Arsenal appearances: 79
Arsenal goals: 2
Jorginho made 213 appearances for Chelsea and won the Champions League, Europa League, UEFA Super Cup and FIFA Club World Cup at Stamford Bridge.
After trying to sign the midfielder in the summer of 2020, Mikel Arteta finally brought him to Arsenal in January 2023 in a deal worth an initial Â£10million and another Â£2million in add-ons.
â€œI want to say too, the warm welcome from the fans as well was so important for me, because I need to be honest, you know, coming from Chelsea, I was like, â€˜OK, letâ€™s see whatâ€™s going to happen here.â€™ I made the decision that I will be myself and hope they like me,â€ he said.
â€œThen as soon as I arrived, I could feel the warm â€”really warmâ€” welcome from the people in the training ground, from the fans on the streets, at the stadium, on social media.
â€œIt made it so easy for me to feel integrated. It was really nice, and now Iâ€™m here, I try to help the new players have that same journey.â€
The Italy international proved to be an astute signing and his leadership qualities saw him handed the captainâ€™s armband on multiple occasions.
He made 79 appearances in all competitions during his two-and-a-half-year stint with the Gunners before joining Flamengo on a free transfer.

1. Petr Cech
Year: 2015
Arsenal appearances: 139
Arsenal goals conceded: 158
Cech established himself as one of the best goalkeepers in the world during his 11 years at Chelsea and won 15 trophies, including four Premier League titles and the Champions League.
After he lost his place in the team to Thibaut Courtois in the 2014/15 season, the Gunners offered him a chance to stay in London.
â€œHe [Roman Abramovich] wasnâ€™t too happy, and didnâ€™t want to see me in that [Arsenal] shirt, but he knew Iâ€™d done everything for his club,â€ he said.
â€œI expressed the reasons why, and he kind of closed his eyes and said: â€˜OK, you can go.â€™ I was nervous because I didnâ€™t have a plan B.â€
He enjoyed an impressive debut season at Arsenal, keeping 16 clean sheets in the Premier League and winning the Golden Glove as the Gunners finished second.
The former Czech Republic international added another FA Cup and two Community Shields to his CV but errors began to creep into his game as his time at Arsenal wore on.
He also struggled to adapt to Unai Emeryâ€™s style of playing out from the back and was eventually usurped by Bernd Leno during the 2018/19 campaign.
Cechâ€™s final game for the Gunners was the 2019 Europa League final against Chelsea but his old side put four goals past him to win the trophy.
